newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Senate bill gives states lead in electricity.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Senate bill gives states lead in electricity.

text.p: Electric utility deregulation would largely be left up to the states under legislation introduced in the U.S. Senate Thursday.

At a Senate Energy Committee meeting on electricity restructuring, Wyoming Republican Craig Thomas said he would introduce a bill to let states take the lead in restructuring, without imposing federal mandates for competition by a certain date.

"If the Congress is going to make fundamental changes to the last major regulated monopoly, its role should be to help implement competitive changes in a positive manner, rather than interject the heavy hand of government with a 'Washington-knows-best' mentality," Thomas said.
"This is a consensus bill that will give lawmakers, who want to see states have the opportunity and the power to deregulate the industry, a thoughtful option to support," he said.

The bill would give each state and non-regulated utility authority over retail transactions to allow stranded costs recovery, and would give states authority to make electricity providers help offer universal service to all classes of consumers.
The bill would repeal the Public Utility Holding Company Act and would lift requirements of the Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act for new contacts.
Senate Energy Committee Chairman Frank Murkowski, an Alaska Republican, has also said he does not want the federal government to interfere with states' restructuring efforts.
Murkowski held the session to look at the effects of increased utility competition on fuel use and types of generation.
